awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Role of Prior Knowledge in Consolidation of Novel Phonotactic Patterns for Speech Production
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Learning a new language opens up a myriad of opportunities for cross-cultural communication, which is critical to remaining competitive in today's globally networked information economy. But language learning is difficult, especially for adults, who must integrate new language experience with the language knowledge they already have. Previous research has found that sleep-based consolidation - an improvement in what you can recall as a result of sleep - is critical to this integration. In fact, we must sleep before novel phonotactics - language-specific generalizations about how sounds can be ordered within syllables and words - become ingrained in speech processing (specifically, unconsciously shaping the errors we make while speaking). This project asks what role prior knowledge plays in this process: Can knowing similar phonotactics boost the effectiveness of sleep-based consolidation for learning novel phonotactics? The findings of this research can inform the design of curricula and interventions to make language learning more effective, and can also shed light on how our brain changes as we learn. The project also includes the training of an undergraduate student as a research assistant and involves outreach about language learning to inform the larger public.

This project aims to clarify the role of prior knowledge in consolidating second-order phonotactic generalizations for speech production, by analyzing errors made in multi-day tongue-twister experiments that manipulate the structural similarity of novel second-order phonotactic generalizations with respect to previously-learned phonotactic generalizations. Structural similarity is operationalized in terms of syllabic positions involved in each generalization (onset-vowel, vowel-coda). Two sources of prior knowledge are considered: participants' native language and pre-training using the experimental tongue-twister task. Activity monitors estimating time spent in slow-wave sleep are used to link consolidation effects observed in this study to those observed in studies in other cognitive and linguistic domains. To control for temporal-order differences between onset-vowel vs. vowel-coda generalizations, a non-linguistic button-pressing task tests for the absence of differences in learning start-middle vs. middle-end patterns. The project also includes the training of an undergraduate student as a research assistant and involves outreach about language learning to inform the larger public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

In this study, we investigated how adults' prior knowledge shapes their learning of a new language's phonotactics -- language-specific generalizations about how sounds can be ordered within syllables and words -- by analyzing how new phonotactics influence speech production in a tongue-twister task. Phonotactics that were previously learned in the context of our study did affect learning of new, analogous phonotactics later on. Specifically, it was harder for participants to learn a rule like "/z/ is always at the end of syllables" if they previously recited tongue-twisters where the analogous consonant /s/ was always at the start of syllables (as opposed to tongue-twisters where /s/ was always at the end). This is the first time that transfer from previous knowledge has been found in this task, adding to our understanding of how representations of phonotactics interact as they are learned in succession.

The interference from previously-learned conflicting phonotactics lessened after 24 hours, suggesting that sleep-based consolidation -- an improvement in what you can recall as a result of sleep -- may have helped participants overcome the conflict. We did not find any other overnight changes in phonotactic knowledge. Taken together with previous work, our findings support the theory that sleep-based consolidation resolves interference between conflicting consonant-position mappings in phonotactic learning. This account explains why sleep-based consolidation mainly benefits the learning of phonotactics that constrain consonants to opposite syllable positions, depending on the identity of the vowel.

In our tongue-twisters, restricted consonants were either constrained to a specific syllable position or not, depending on the identity of the vowel. For example, the restricted consonant /s/ always appeared at the start of syllables containing /a/, but it was free to appear at the start or end of syllables containing /i/. Unrestricted consonants, on the other hand, were free to appear in any position, regardless of the vowel. We found that, even in errors on syllables containing the "free" vowel (/i/ in the example above), restricted consonants still preserved their syllable position more often than unrestricted consonants. This suggests that participants generalized the phonotactic information across vowel contexts, adding to our understanding of how phonotactics are represented for speech production.

Across the board, consonants at the ends of syllables were more likely to preserve their syllable position in errors than those that appeared at the beginning of syllables. We did not find this pattern in our non-linguistic control experiment (where participants pressed sequence of buttons instead of reciting tongue-twisters). This serves as evidence that additional biases shape speech production, beyond those governing other sequential actions.

Overall, this study clarifies the role of prior knowledge and sleep in adult phonotactic learning for speech production. Thanks to this work, we have a better understanding of how adults' prior knowledge shapes the dynamics of phonotactic learning, and of how phonotactic generalizations are represented in the mind for speech production.

Broader Impacts

The interference effects we found are evidence that the languages adults already know (particularly ones learned in similar contexts, such as a classroom) can interfere with their learning of phonotactic restrictions, especially early on. Language teachers can use this knowledge to provide extra scaffolding and motivation for adult learners who have experience learning other languages in a classroom setting -- specifically, other languages with phonotactic generalizations that differ significantly from the one being taught.

In the course of this project, we recruited a research assistant. This research assistant received individualized training in experimental desgin and statistical analysis of data from both the co-PI and PI, and is currently involved in her own independent research.

This project also created several resources that will aid researchers in conducting their own online studies. The code for the web application that we used to collect data has been made public, allowing other researchers to run versions of our online experiments using their own stimulus lists. With participants' permissions, recordings of speech data are publicly available on Open Science Foundation website, enabling other researchers to examine the quality of recordings that are obtainable using participants' home computers and microphones. These recordings may also be used to train junior speech researchers to perform analysis on data collected outside the lab.
